articles.headline: Siemens Chief Says He Will Step Down
articles.snippet: Klaus Kleinfeld is the latest casualty in the German engineering company’s widening corruption scandal.
articles.abstract: Klaus Kleinfeld is the latest casualty in the German engineering company’s widening corruption scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, April 25 — The embattled chief executive of Siemens, Klaus Kleinfeld, said Wednesday that he would step down when his contract expired in September, the latest casualty in a widening corruption scandal that has shaken corporate Germany.

articles.headline: Singapore Makes a Pitch to Draw the Wealthy
articles.snippet: Singapore is trying to carve out a new niche for itself in the global economy by bolstering banking secrecy laws and offering generous tax incentives.
articles.abstract: Singapore is trying to carve out a new niche for itself in the global economy by bolstering banking secrecy laws and offering generous tax incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, April 25 — This affluent city-state of 4.5 million people is aiming to be a sanctuary for the world’s wealthy and their money, Asia’s answer to Geneva and Zurich.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Moves to Restrict TV Violence
articles.snippet: Proposed regulations would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching.
articles.abstract: Proposed regulations would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 25 — Concerned about an increase in violence on television, the Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday urged lawmakers to consider regulations that would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching.

articles.headline: After Saudis’ First Steps, Efforts for Reform Stall
articles.snippet: Recently the government has cracked down on advocates of change and scrapped some long-promised initiatives.
articles.abstract: Recently the government has cracked down on advocates of change and scrapped some long-promised initiatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — It was a scene to warm the heart of any democrat. Here in this autocratic kingdom, elected city councilmen vowed to stand up for poor fishermen and ask the government to ensure that a large section of seafront on which a new university is planned be left accessible to local residents.

articles.headline: Rival Bid for ABN Amro Is $98.5 Billion
articles.snippet: The offer by the Royal Bank of Scotland and other lenders trumps the Barclays bid in the biggest takeover battle in banking industry.
articles.abstract: The offer by the Royal Bank of Scotland and other lenders trumps the Barclays bid in the biggest takeover battle in banking industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 25 — Royal Bank of Scotland, the British bank, and two other European lenders on Wednesday opened the biggest takeover battle in banking industry by offering 72.2 billion euros, or $98.5 billion, for ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank.

articles.headline: Run on Wall Street Sends Dow Above 13,000
articles.snippet: The rally has defied skeptics who thought stocks were due for a harder slog as the economy slows.
articles.abstract: The rally has defied skeptics who thought stocks were due for a harder slog as the economy slows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Far from being the cruelest month, April has turned out to be one of the most profitable in recent memory for investors in the stock market.
